Award.AbstractNarration:
EarthCube is a community-driven effort with the goal of transforming the conduct of geoscience research and education by creating a well-integrated and facile environment to share scientific data, information tools and services, and knowledge in an open, transparent, and inclusive manner. Under the leadership of University Corporation for Atmospheric Research (UCAR) and in partnership with the EarthCube community, its governance, and other stakeholders and collaborators, the EarthCube Science Support Office (ESSO) will support efforts to advance EarthCube's mission. ESSO's role will be to provide a logistical, organizational, and administrative foundation to facilitate the advancement of EarthCube goals to catalyze scientific breakthroughs in the geosciences by fostering advances in information and computational sciences. ESSO will endeavor to ensure a high quality of service to EarthCube stakeholders, delivered with professionalism, efficiency, transparency, and nimbleness.

ESSO will provide logistical support to the EarthCube community and its governance groups in order to stimulate and manage community dialog, strengthen efforts to define and resolve common challenges using a consensus-oriented approach, and help realize EarthCube's full potential and vision. ESSO will provide leadership to improve the coherence and impact of EarthCube's efforts, bringing a coordinated and well-integrated approach to managing and supporting governance, science, and technology activities. To accomplish this, UCAR will draw on the expertise of two of its community programs -- Unidata and the Joint Office for Science Support (JOSS) -- to provide the services requested of the ESSO. In addition, ESSO will collaborate with the Earth Science Information Partners (ESIP) Federation to leverage their long experience with the geoscience cyberinfrastructure community for the mutual benefit of both organizations and their communities. ESSO will also spearhead outreach and community engagement activities by participating in national and international scientific society meetings, scientific career fairs, and other events. ESSO will reach out to broader audiences through the EarthCube website, newsletters, and social media. It will leverage the presence of geoscientists and cyberinfrastructure professionals to offer in-person and virtual seminars, promoting the work of funded projects, data facilities, and providing backbone support for education, training, and workforce development activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The EarthCube program, which began in 2011, seeks to accelerate our ability to understand and predict the Earth system by creating a well-connected cyberinfrastructure for sharing and integrating data, tools, services and knowledge across all geoscience disciplines in an open, transparent, and inclusive manner. With the help of the EarthCube Science Support Office (ESSO), funded by this award, more than 2,500 community members have helped shape the design, direction, and evolution of EarthCube — participating in its governance, helping set its priorities, and actively designing and building cyberinfrastructure. In doing so, EarthCube has fostered collaborations and built agile interdisciplinary communities that span geoscience domains and facilitated data and resource discovery.

This project was tasked with providing logistical support for EarthCube, including providing the necessary information, supporting infrastructure, and services to ensure that EarthCube’s portfolio of governance programs and projects were effectively and efficiently directed, managed and delivered. ESSO’s responsibilities included communication and outreach, community engagement, management of subawards, and the advancement of EarthCube’s cyberinfrastructure. Specifically, ESSO

Provided logistics and administrative support for EarthCube governance

ESSO supported all of EarthCube’s permanent and temporary committees and teams. These include the Leadership Council, Technology and Architecture Committee, Council for Data Facilities, Science Committee, Engagement Team, Liaison Team, Nominations Committee, EarthCube Advisory Group, and Annual Meeting Committees. For each group ESSO arranged meetings, facilitated and recorded what happened, completed tasks assigned, and followed up with chairs to make sure that next steps take place.

Document Management

ESSO helped the volunteer community, by creating, facilitating and maintaining a wide range of documents during the program period. These included a Priorities Document, Architecture and Implementation Plan, Response Documents, Roadmap, Committee and Team Charters, and Communications Plan.

Management of Subawards

The office has supported the solicitation, award and monitoring of a number of subawards. These have included the Architecture and Implementation Plan, two Data Registry projects, a project to develop a graphical user interface for EarthCube’s data registry, and the EarthCube Resource Registry. The technical officer worked with all projects to ensure that they remain on budget and within scope, as well as helping to decide changes and updates.

EarthCube Annual Meeting (formerly EarthCube All Hands Meeting)

ESSO has supported and developed the three most recent EarthCube Annual Meetings. These were the major event for the program each year, with over 150 attendees spending three days discussing progress and next steps. Planning and facilitating the meeting takes a large part of each year and a significant number of ESSO staff members. Feedback has been consistent and strongly supportive of the work carried out by the office on these events. 

 Conference Outreach

Appearances and talks at scientific conferences, poster presentations, birds-of-a-feather sessions, town halls, and workshops have been held at domain conferences across the country. ESSO planned, facilitated and improved exhibit spaces. These increased outreach and community engagement. Events included meetings of the Geological Society of America, American Geophysical Union, Association for the Sciences of Limnology and Oceanograhy, American Meteorological Society, Earth Science Information Partners, ESIP, and the European Geosciences Union. EarthCube materials were circulated at all conferences, as well as informational literature and electronic presentations.

 Communication & Engagement

ESSO worked to increase community engagement, through:

●     Website - Over three years, the EarthCube website was overhauled to improve user experience.

●     Social Media - Efforts to increase EarthCube’s presence, popularity and reach.

●     Newsletters—Monthly EarthCube newsletters are distributed to all members.

●     Weekly Updates—The weekly Monday EarthCube Update continues to grow in popularity.

Advancement of EarthCube Cyberinfrastructure

Under the leadership of the Technical Officer within ESSO, this project also successfully delivered, deployed, and maintained the cloud-based software services, registries, and user interfaces for the core data and software registry, discovery, and access needs for the geoscience community utilizing web standards for interoperability. 

In summary, during the period of performance of this award, major strides were by EarthCube on multiple fronts. In particular, ESSO’s efforts to enhance EarthCube’s reputation in the community by expanding EarthCube’s outreach content highlighting project were quite successful.
